cwe_description: The product reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of an intended buffer.
explanation: The code contains an out-of-bounds read vulnerability. In the loop populating input_types, the index ix (derived from edge->src_output()) is used to access node_t.args(ix). A DCHECK validates ix against node_t.args_size(), but DCHECKs are often disabled in release builds. If edge->src_output() is controlled by an attacker and exceeds node_t.args_size(), an out-of-bounds read will occur, potentially leading to information disclosure or a denial of service.

A DCHECK validates ix against node_t.args_size(), but DCHECKs are often disabled in release builds. If edge->src_output() is controlled by an attacker and exceeds node_t.args_size(), an out-of-bounds read will occur, potentially leading to information disclosure or a denial of service.

cwe_description: The software reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of the intended buffer. This can lead to crashes, information disclosure, or other undefined behavior.
explanation: The code uses a DCHECK to validate an array index (ix) before accessing node_t.args(ix). In release builds, DCHECKs are typically compiled out, removing this bounds check. If an attacker can control the value of ix (derived from edge->src_output()) such that it is greater than or equal to node_t.args_size(), an out-of-bounds read will occur when calling node_t.args(ix). This can lead to a crash (Denial of Service) or potentially an information leak.
